Inscription on copyright page: 17 July 79  Dear Ms. Welty, I hope this volume, but one of your English admirers, will remind you of a beautiful, well spent summer.   We have all enjoyed our brief contact with you. For now we know you as a person, and it was your thought about knowing & understanding others that helped me enjoy your reading and our once-in-a-while chats. So refreshing.  Your Friend, Rob Rubers (?) Note:

title: A Vision Shared: A Classic Portrait of America and Its People 1935-1943
creator: Hank O'Neal
subject: Photography
description:
Inscription:
"30 March 1982 / For Eudora, with deepest gratitude for all the kindness and generosity shown me on my visit in March, 1982.  I hope you will find time to enjoy looking at these eloquent faces and places captured by photographers whose vision, unwittingly at the time, you shared.  But I'm so glad that your blessedly inescapable and wonderfully developed gift led you to chose literature over the lens; and my gratitude to you, which goes very deep, is always, always and mostly, for your beautiful fiction.  It has formed for me, for most of my adult life (this is also the 20th anniversary of my book on your fiction!), "a vision shared" - of life itself - a way of seeing, valuing, growing, suffering through, delighting in, and loving it! / Denotedly, / Ruth" Note: A collection of photos. taken by the photographers of the U.S. Farm Security Administration.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: A Curtain of Green
creator: Eudora Welty
subject: Fiction
description: Inscription on first page: "To Mother / in love, gratitude + happiness / Eudora / New York City / November 4, 1941" Note: Introduction by Katherine Anne Porter. When John Woodburn came through Jackson in the spring of 1940 on a scouting expedition on behalf of Doubleday, Doran, he met Eudora and eventually suggested that she approach Diarmuid Russell to become her agent. Woodburn indicated, too, that his firm would like to publish Eudora’s seventeen early stories in a volume eventually entitled A Curtain of Green. A contract was offered to Eudora in late January 1941 with a publication date set for November 7, 1941 (Polk 441–44). On October 23, 1942, Doubleday, Doran published The Robber Bridegroom, likewise edited by Woodburn (Polk 446). After Woodburn wrote Eudora on Thanksgiving Day of that year that he had taken a job at Harcourt, Brace, she agreed to switch publishing houses and continue with him as her editor.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Complete and Poetry and Selected Prose
creator: John Donne
subject: Anthology
description: Eudora Welty’s name is inscribed in four places. First, on the front free endpaper in ink “Eudora Welty / 1929” and secondly, on the blank recto page preceding the title page “Eudora Welty” and third, on back pasted-in endpaper hand printed in black “Eudora Welty.” The fourth is in pencil on back free endpaper: “Eudora Welty / 325 N. Francis / Madison, Wis—“. Also, on page 296, the last 2 ½ lines of “The Martyrs” which is one of the Divine Poems #X, the following is underlined by hand, presumably by Welty: “. . . a discreet patience / Of death, or of worse life : for Oh, to some / Not to be Martyrs, is a martyrdome.” On verso of back flyleaf in pencil are written addresses on bottom half of page and on top half of page are possibly phone numbers. Note:

On page 530: "In the Twilight / By Eudora Welty (Age 15) / January 1925 / (Gold Badge. Silver Badge won August, 1920)" and the 12-line poem of rhyming couplets follows. So I send / you the book with love. / Victor Pritchett”. 
Inscribed on the title page is the holograph, “VS Pritchett”.  Note: Eudora Welty’s short story, “A Visit of Charity” is included in the anthology.

Cummings – The Enormous Room / [. . . ]. On final free endpaper at bottom and upside down “Psych. 8:00 Tues. June 18 / lecture material [?] 223 Bascom / Educ. 8:00 Wed. June 19. / Art 2:30 Fri. title: The Sound and the Fury / As I Lay Dying
creator: William Faulkner
subject: Fiction
description:
In viewer’s left margin of last printed page in the book is written in pencil: “290 Jason [?] / 301 / 303 / 311 / 318 / 324 sequence / is [?] all / 336 / sequence / Benjy”. 
Beginning at top of recto of last free endpaper in pencil: “Time / - & Corruption” at top viewer’s left and “C. 5 / 7” top viewer’s right / “I [Roman numeral 1] Benjy – timelessness in (p. 19) / or fixed in time, 36 / or time composed [confused?] / It’s his birthday, a time marker / p. 44 but - / senses not dependent on course [?] of time / (unless [?] seeing [?] Benjy. 9/etc.” Below a line are addition inscriptions that correspond to page numbers: “Question / opens with watch, p. 95-6, 99 / 102. 123, 138,-9 (171 some with / Coddy) / like [?] father’s rhetoric) 189 / 187”.
Following this, and linked by a dotted line on the viewer’s left: “homesick 102, 104, 105, 118, 187-8 / Transitions in the mind: 133-4, 182 / 187-8 / Frozen moments: 100 in the mirror running / 134 got to marry somebody / 143 & earlier – one minute she / was standing in the door. 152 & 168, 170 honeysuckle”. 
At bottom: “154 ‘Where do you live, sister?’ joined them / 168 with she stood in the door.” 
In margin on viewer’s left, vertically aligned is “188 – images coalesce”.  Passages are underlined throughout the book. Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

description:
Inscriptions, all handwritten in pencil are as follows:
Title page at top: “I. [or possibly “J” or even “T”] P. B.”
On memoranda page for January and on the blank line beside line numbered “4” (for January 4th) is “Drifting Snow” and beside no. 10 is “very cold indeed”.
On memoranda page for March beside no. 1 is “Surprise party at [Mother? Martha?] Briggs”.
On memoranda page for June beside no. 5 and no. 6 is “Ellen Birney died at 1/2 [indecipherable] P.M. / in her 25th year”.
On memo page for September on line beside no. 9 is [indecipherable name] aged 96 die [sic]” and on the line beside no. 10 is “went to funeral” and by no. 12 is “came home” and beside no. 20 is “went to Martha’s in Ch[?]” and by no. 23 is “came back”. Note:

title: A Book of Saints and Wonders
creator: Lady Gregory
description: Inscribed on front free endpaper in black ink, “For Eudora, / with love from Edward. / July 1979.” On page 5 viewer’s right lower margin is “le” handwritten beside the printed word, “talks” which appears to have a line drawn through the “k”. Inscribed in pencil on rear free endpaper is “33 / 35 / 36”.  Note: Inserted between pages 84 and 85 is a printed, tri-folded invitation on paper with the following printed inside: “Mississippi Society to Prevent Blindness / Membership Luncheon / Wednesday, November 28 / 12:00 Noon / in the home of Mrs. H. E. Allen / 418 Glenway / RSVP by November 21 to / Mrs. Bill Mayfield / 60 Woodridge Place / Jackson, Ms. 39211” and struck-through is “Five dollars per person”. This is printed inside an illustration of a wreath, below which is handwritten, “Please be our guest. We hope / you can come to our Auxiliary / luncheon.” The top and bottom of the paper overlap and a gold adhesive label seals it and is still attached to top. Above the seal is stamped “Prevention of Blindness Auxiliary” and below this are two blue stamps, one illegible and the other “J8”, probably a postal service stamp. The front is addressed by hand to “Miss Eudora Welty / 1119 Pinehurst St. / Jackson, Miss. 39202” with return address “115 Broadmoor Dr. / Jackson, MS 39206” all handwritten in ink script with a postage stamp of a waving American flag and with “USA 15¢ / The Land of the Free – The Home of the Brave” in all caps printed on the stamp.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

description:
Inscribed upon front free endpaper in black ink is “Eudora Welty / New York – March, 1935”. 
Inscribed on recto of rear free endpaper in pencil appears to be “To get the money from Miss A [rgyle?] so Minnie Lee can get / married to / her beau / before he / is drafted.” Also “Each task Miss Argyle [?] asks it finally / sit [?] down & 2 little negro twins / Georg & Norge [?], & 1 of them puts / on the black [calfskin?]-tail cap [or cop?] / flags the Memphis bus & rides a / mile in town & asks his / uncle Leepo sassafras man Lou [Love?] to do it. / Uncle Leepo the sassafras man.”
Marked on page 23 in the margin is “x GB” next to the line by Apollo to Daphne: “’Since you cannot be my wife,’ said he, ‘you shall assuredly be my / harp and my quiver [. . . .]” Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Vanity Fair: A Cavalcade of the 1920s and 1930s
subject: Anthology
description:
Note: Bookmarks:
Two blank “sticky note” or adhesive notes hang off the proper left side of the fore edge on two pages. Bookmark 1 is on p. 199 center proper left side. Page 199 features two couples with biographies and photographs by Edward Steichen. The couples are actors Edna Best with Herbert Marshall and actor Norma Shearer and Hollywood producer Irving Thalberg. Bookmark 2 is on page 217 where the story “The Pearly Beach” by Lord Dunsany appears with a photograph of Lord and Lady Dunsany.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Aperture, no. 81
subject: Photography
description:
Note:  Pages 48 – 59 feature an essay “Eudora Welty: Guy Davenport celebrates a writer & photographer” with 14 black and white photographs by Eudora Welty. 
Bookmarks:
Bookmark 1 is a yellow sticky note on which is written in black ink, probably in Eudora Welty’s hand, “1st Choice”. This book mark is on the bottom of page 52 under a photograph by Welty depicting a group of girls in dresses surrounding a woman dressed in white. The title of the photo might be “Sunday School Classroom”. 
Bookmark 2 is also a yellow sticky note on which is written “ALTERNATE” in black ink probably in Welty’s hand and it is below a Welty photo of a woman dressed in white with a white polka-dot blouse. The woman is standing outside under a covered walkway or sidewalk and beside a rounded suitcase. Her hand is on her hip and she looks as if she’s waiting for someone.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: The Language of Flowers
creator: E.W.L.
description:
On front endpapers there is drawing and an inscription. 
On front paste-down is the drawing, which drawing depicts a heart that contains “EW” at top part of the heart with a lock drawn between the initials and initialed and dated “dp / 91”. Below the drawing is inscribed, “Fondly, Dawn Podell / Palo Alto, Ca/ 1991”
On the front free endpaper is inscribed: 
“To Eudora Welty, / You have given me / years, nights, days, and / afternoons of pleasure. I will / always treasure the vision of / the tiny ‘Powerhouse of a Woman’ / walking down the aisle at Stanford University / with a real / true ‘pocketbook’. I was in the company of my friend Helen Bowman Moulton, / (orig. near Natchez, La [sic]) who introduced me to your / books. I am forever grateful for her and them. / If you do not have this book, the / writer of the ‘Optimist’s Daughter’ / should! Hearing you read your / work in person has made all / of it more so. Helen cried / when I gave her new / book of snapshots / It gives me confidence / to continue / without / technique” Note: Facsim. ed. of original ms. dated August 8th, 1913, and signed F.W.L. (Father).
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

S. Lewis (W2005.1.2896). The old accession number on the back of the business card corresponds to that of "Truth and vision in Katherine Anne Porter's fiction" by Darlene Harbour Unrue. On the bottom of the business card, there is a hand-drawn circle around the address, the printed office number is crossed out, and below it are the printed home number and a handwritten office phone number. The seal of the University of Nevada, Las Vegas is embossed in red at top center.

creator: Walker; William Evans; Christenberry
subject: Photography
description:
Inscribed on title page in all caps except for the signature: "For Eudora Welty / in gratitude and / in friendship / Bill Christenberry / March 20, 1991". Note: Insert: Between pages 64 and 65 was a top-folded note card from William Christenberry featuring one of his sculptures on note card front. Inscribed inside the card is the following in all caps except for the signature: "Washington, D.C. / March 26, 1991 / Dear Miss Welty / I wish to thank you again / for my visit to your home. / On April 9 I return to Millsaps for my last visit, and if convenient for you, I hope to see you again. 
"It is with great pleasure that I send you the enclosed / book. Sincerely, / Bill Christenberry", and on back of the card is handwritten "William Christenberry / 2739 Macomb St. N.W. / Washington, D.C. 20008".

title: Kashtanka
creator: Anton Chekhov
subject: Fiction
description:
Inscribed on title page: 
"for Eudora Welty with my greatest respect / and affection. / Barry Moser". Note: Inserts: 
1) A yellow sticky note is adhered to the table of contents page. The note expresses regret by the illustrator, Barry Moser, that his dedication for Eudora Welty was placed [by the publisher] on the copyright page. Due to the risk of damaging the note if removed, it remains in the book.
2) Inserted between pages 14 and 15 was a letter dated May 15, 1991, handwritten in calligraphy from Barry Moser to Eudora Welty. In the letter, Moser explains why he dedicated the book to Eudora Welty and he mentions the illustrations that he did for new HBJ paperbacks of her work. At top of the stationery is printed "Bear Run."
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Vita's Other World: A Gardening Biography of V. Sackville-West
creator: Jane Brown
subject: Non-fiction
description:
There are marginalia or emphases (underlines or marks next to a passage) on the following pages with some being more legible than others:
p. 12 emphases added in right margin
p. 13 at top “like JF – a love story” and above “Peter Quinnell” which is circled is “quote original”. There are two more inscriptions on left and right margins, but they’re illegible.
p. 14 “lack of central perspective” in left margin
p. 15 “…location but is escape” [?] in right margin
p. 19 “’the largest house in England still in private hands’” underlined
p. 20 “the great house” and “four acres of it” are underlined
p. 28 “Knole’s garden” and “six acres were” are underlined
p. 41 “…write in relation to the gardens in her life – a different emphasis”
pp. 84 and 85
p. 177 “as the war starts – death and doom hang [hung?] in the air [illegible]”
p. 178 “and love / letters [?] between / them too”
p. 179 [something about birthday and Christmas presents]
p. 202 “toward / the / end of her life”
p. 215 illegible note in right margin and emphasis added to “end of the twenties” and “anti-socialness became a way of life” in the text.
p. 219 “[evolution? creation?] / of / ideal / refuge – / not / the / [illegible] / itself”
p. 234 two paragraphs of notes including “…some people are warmed in garden but they [acted out?]…” and “Unlike HF & Collette, V. ended up not / a writer who gardened, but a gardener who / wrote.” Note: Between pages 178 and 179 was a facsimile review of "Vita's Other World" by Jeffrey Paine from an unidentified publication.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Persuasion
creator: Jane Austen
subject: Romance
description:
Eudora Welty underlined and marked numerous passages in pencil throughout the book. Beginning on the last page, verso and continuing onto the recto are notes in the form of an index written in pencil by Eudora Welty as follows:
"Part One [underlined]
31. 
32 Conversation begins with Chap. 3
40.
44. 
54. 
55.
75 introspective. Insight.
90 Walter on her back, 1st stop
93.
98. The nut. Let those who would be happy be firm 
      cf 126 after accident
99. Capt & Louisa
101. Capt. makes her ride, 2nd stop [?]
101. The way of driving the gig – like the nut
         her literary instincts 
        & sharpness 
105-6, Lyme – the scene – out of season - 
106-7 Capt. Benwick intro. 117 Anne’s recommendation, 
        110
110. poetry & feeling.
>111.
113. Lady Russell desc. [?]
118. The accident – the fall from the cobb
*126. Persuasion vs. firmness, after L’s accident
-------- [Here, a short horizontal line is drawn from the margin on the free edge of the page to under “*126”.]
143, 146. Mr. Elliot also hopes to un-do the past.
          sub-plot [?] variation on love story
148. Sir Walter & the faces of Bath 
160. Anne descr. [?]”

[Index continues onto recto:]
“161.
167  Mr Elliot, 211, 212, 215
172. Elizabeth Elliot.
172. Capt. Benwick, 222
173.  “            “         & Louisa
x185 – Anne’s thought of Lady R’s through of Capt. W
         -- and wrong. 
189 – Capt. W. on Louise
190. Everything in groups, throughout 
x191. resolution. [illegible]: the tenderness
          of the past. 
191. concert. next stop 
197 Austen cruelty & mockery 
211.” Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: My Mortal Enemy
creator: Willa Cather
subject: Fiction
description:
Handwritten on the last page is "35" in pencil. It appears to be in Eudora Welty's hand and conforms to her indexing practice with some books. There are two small corresponding marks in the right margin on top of page 35 next to the following two sentences: 
"The next evening, as we were walking across [this is where the first mark appears]
the Square to the Henshawes, we glanced up and
saw them standing together in one of their deep 
front windows, framed by the plum-coloured cur- 
tains."
"When she was peaceful, she was like a dove with [this is where the second mark appears]
its wings folded." Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

The bookmark is cream colored with a silhouette illustration of a seated figure touching an open book on a book stand. On verso are the artwork credits.

title: Destination
creator: Gerald Langford
subject: Fiction
description: Inscription: on front free endpaper, “For Eudora Welty -- / I kept brushing away the crumbly / edges and compressing the lump / until it finally hardened and / held its shape -- one that I / hope you will find appealing / Gerald Langford”. Note: Inserted inside front cover is a typed note signed "Jerry" on University of Texas at Austin, Department of English letterhead dated May 24, 1983: "Dear Eudora, / The other day I was discussing with some / students your beautiful story 'No Place for You, / My Love,' and it suddenly came over me that I / had not, somehow, sent you a copy of my Savannah / novel when it finally came out.  Certainly I had / meant to, but when I checked I could find no / record of having done so. I was dismayed. / Let me send one herewith, belated though / it is, for I really believe the story will in- / terest you if you can spare a couple of hours / sometime. / We shall hope for a chance to see you / again one day. / Warmest greetings, / Jerry". Spine of book is creased.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: A Month in the Country

subject: Fiction
description:
Note: Two inserts were found inside back endpapers: 1) A postcard with a reproduction of Manet's "My Garden" on one side and on verso is a typed and handwritten message signed in blue ink "Frank C. Platt" and dated "Oct 12 '83". The message is about this book, and at the bottom is handwritten in black ink, "Eudora [or Enclosed?], a example / of his [publications]". The postcard has been scanned and was transferred to Archives. 
2) A small pink and black paperback booklet on the cover of which is "John Keats," which is edited by Elizabeth Farrer and published by J. L. Carr, is also inserted in the back; this booklet has been cataloged as W2005.1.5266.

title: Paradise Plume
creator: Mary Roelofs Stott
description:
There are four inserts between pages 50 and 51, and they are as follows: 
1) A letter dated 5 January 1989 from the author to Eudora Welty. The letter is part fan letter and introduces her book, “Paradise Plume”, which she sent with the letter along with the other inserts. 
2) Three pages folded together: a list dated April 1988 of Mary Roelofs Stott’s publications and two pages dated December 1988 of reviews. 
3) A photocopied clipping from “The Swarthmorean” on October 14, 1988, about the author and “Paradise Plume”.
4) A clipping, which is from the 25 December 1988 issue of “The Living Church” of an article by Mary Roelofs Stott. Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Christian Perfection
creator: François de Salignac de La Mothe Fénelon
subject: Non-fiction
description:
Inscriptions:
On front free endpaper is inscribed “For my daughter, Nancy / (eventually) / Caroline [or Earmine? difficult to read] Tate / The Red House / and, in the meantime, for my dear friend, / Eudora Welty / who, if she reads in it / carefully enough, will / find it a mirror of some / of her own virtues, / [illegible but possibly ‘Caroline’ or ‘Earmine’] Gordon”.  
On back fly leaf is inscribed in what appears to be the same hand, “Soc. Sec. 108-26-9756 / Father Damien, O.C.D.  Carmelite / Monastery, 2131 Lincoln Road / N.E., Washington, D.C. / Pilgrimage to International / Congress of Discalced / Carmelite Third Order / O.C.D.” Book is also annotated. Note: "Translation of Fénelon's Instructions et avis sur divers points de la morale et de la perfection chrétienne ... made from the Lefèvre, Paris, 1858 edition ... and checked ... with the Lebel, Paris, 1823 edition."
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Freshwater Fishes in Mississippi
creator: Fannye A. Cook
subject: Non-fiction
description:
Inscribed on title page in blue ink:
"Dear Mrs. Welty: / I shall always treasure / your friendship and be / grateful for your sweet / thoughtfulness of me during / the many years this report / was in progress. / Love and good wishes for the best / of everything. / Frances Cook / March, '60". Note: Association copy. Conservationist and scientist Fannye A. Cook (born 1889 in Crystal Springs, Miss.; died 1964) led the campaign to establish the Mississippi Game and Fish Commission in 1932 and the state's wildlife museum in 1939. She boarded in the Welty home for about 15 years until about 1955 or 1956.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Eudora Welty
creator: Ruth M. Vande Kieft
subject: Non-fiction
description: Inscription on front free end paper, “March 1987 / To Eudora – devotedly, and / with profound gratitude for your / wonderful fiction, and the generous / gift of your friendship. It pleases / me to think I was already “following / your career” as a small girl, as / the editors have it (inside, jacket) : / I knew something wonderful was in / store for me! / I hope my words will be worthy of / yours, and help readers to enjoy / your stories. / with much love from / Ruth” in blue ink. Note:
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Literature in Performance 2, no. 1 (November 1981
creator: University of North Carolina Chapel Hill
subject: Periodical
description: Note: Letter found folded in half and inserted between pages 54 and 55 reads, “6 November 1981 / Miss Eudora Welty / 1119 Pinehurst St. / Jackson, Miss. 39202 / Dear Miss Welty, / I am sending you the enclosed because my good friend, and yours, Joanna / Maclay advised me to do so. Otherwise, I don’t think I’d have the nerve. / Please know that the article was a labor of love. / Very truly yours, / [signed] / Thomas O. Sloane” typed on a typewriter and signed in black. The letterhead is from the Department of Rhetoric at the University of California, Berkeley. Sloane was a Professor of Rhetoric and teacher of oral interpretation at the University of California, Berkeley and contributed article, “The Strategies of Authorial Presence: Narrators and Regionalism in Flannery O’Connor and Eudora Welty” beginning on page 1.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

Inscription on title page reads, “for Eudora Welty - / with all my admiration / and affection - / Rosanna / Christmas ‘81” in blue ink pen.
There is a mark on page 42 (last page) that looks like a slash through the ‘t’ of “leaft” in the first line of the poem “Pastorale”. Note: 550 copies printed.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: "Acrobats in the Park" Reprint from Delta, no. 5 (Novembre 1977)
creator: Eudora Welty
description: Note: In Delta, vol. 5, no. 5 (November 1977). This printing of "Acrobats in a Park" is excerpted from a French publication series titled "Delta" with the Greek letter delta replacing the 'a' in the word. The story appeared in Delta No. 5, which was edited by Kenneth Graham. The Delta series was published by The Centre d'étude et de recherches sur les écrivains du Sud aux Etats-Unis de l'Université Paul Valéry in Montpellier, France.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: The Glorious Apology
creator: Eudora Welty
subject: Fiction
description: Note: Eudora Welty wrote and produced this book at age 11 to amuse her brother Edward. Unpublished hardback written circa 1920. It is a black hardback with a reproduction of the cover. A newspaper clipping reads, "What Spell Does This Strange Book cast over its reader?" Handwritten is "The Glorious Apology" by E. Welty. There are other newspaper clippings inside the cover. The inside pages are lined with the story written in ink. The inner pages also contain photos and words cut from newspaper and magazines.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: The Night of the Little House
creator: Eudora Welty
description: Note: This is an early book manuscript written by Welty. Print is done by a typewriter. Paper is only typed on the front side.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: A Christmas Story
creator: Eudora Welty
description: The inside pages are handwritten in pencil, with pencil illustrations. Note: Pages 3-6 are loose from the cover. This was a story written and illustrated by Eudora Welty when she was 8 or 9.
source: Mississippi Department of Archives and History

title: Webster's Collegiate Dictionary
subject: Dictionary
description: Inscriptions: The first page has "Eudora A. Welty 1925" in pen.  The left side of that page has "EYRICH & CO., Jackson, MS" stamped in blue. The last blank page has pencil notes that are illegible.  On the opposite page is "EUDORA WELTY" in capital green letters.  This inscription is followed by "Eudora Welty/ 1119 Pinehurst/ Jackson, Miss/ M.S.C.W - Columbus, Miss./ U. of Wis. - Madison Wis./ Columbia U. - New York City." Note: Held together with black tape and masking tape, book is separated in middle.

creator: Annie Leibovitz
subject: Photography
description: Book is inscribed on title page in black ink: "New York 1997/ for Miss Welty/ Annie Leibovitz." Note: The White Oak Dance Project, a collaborative effort of Mikhail Baryshnikov and choreographer Mark Morris, brought together a small company of dancers in the summer of 1990 to create and learn a new repertory on the White Oak Plantation, a wildlife preserve in northern Florida. The facilities were provided by Howard Gilman, a longtime patron of the arts with a particular interest in dance.
